choices.C: the requirement for a hierarchical IP addressing scheme for optimal functionality
choices.E: the large size of the topology table listing all advertised routes in the converged network
choices.D: the high demand on router resources to run the link-state routing algorithm
choices.A: the sequencing and acknowledgment of link-state packets
choices.B: the high volume of link-state advertisements in a converged network

discussion.content:
I believe Answer C & D are correct:

According to Wendell Odom ICND2 200-105 CCNA Guide - Chapter 7: Understanding OSPF Concepts page 175

Link-state protocols—in particular, Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) and System (IS-IS)—solved the main issues. They also came with a price: 

They required extra CPU and memory on routers, with more planning required from the network engineers.

EIGRP solved the same problems as did link-state routing protocols, but less planning was required when implementing the network.
I’m pretty sure the answer is B and D
I think the answer is D and E

The answer should be D and E.

Explanation:

Large OSPF networks suffer:
- Convergence is slow.
- Topology database requires more memory.
- SPF algorithm requires more processing power, CPU cycles.
- A single interface change ==>> every router runs SPF again.

questions.question_text: What are two drawbacks of implementing a link-state routing protocol? (Choose two.)

comments.content: Don't quote me on this but I'm pretty sure that BGP can advertise any route, not just local to the AS, as long as it appears in the routing table.

questions.question_text: Which purpose of the network command in the BGP configuration of a router is true?

choices.A: It enables route advertisement in the BGP routing process on the router.
choices.C: It advertises a valid network as local to the autonomous system of a router.
choices.D: It indicates whether a neighbor supports route refresh.
choices.B: It advertises any route in BGP with no additional configuration.

questions.question_text: Which two types of cloud services may require you to alter the design of your network infrastructure? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
(Development) Platform as a Service
Platform as a Service (PaaS) is a development platform, prebuilt as a service. A PaaS service
is like IaaS in some ways. Both supply the consumer with one (or more) VMs, with a configurable amount of CPU, RAM, and other resources.

choices.B: Because router RTB will send a poison reverse packet to router RTA, RTA will remove the route.
choices.A: A route to 172.16.14.0/24 will remain in the RTA routing table.
choices.D: A packet to host 172.16.14.225 will be dropped by router RТА.
choices.C: Router RTA will send an ICMP packet to attempt to verify the route.

discussion.content: You can see in the exhibit that the route is defined manually by using the ip route command. As the route was not advertised by a routing protocol, it will remain in the table regardless of whether or not the link goes down for any reason
Why not A, both ip addresses are in the same subnet as well. network 173.15.16.0/20
The correct answer is C. Both ip addresses are in the same subnet range 172.15.30.1 - 172.15.30.62

questions.question_text: Which combination of values is valid for a router-on-a-stick implementation?

choices.D: FastEthernet interface 0/0.20, IP address 173.15.30.33/27, gateway 173.15.30.1 and VLAN 30 C
choices.B: FastEhernet interface 0/0.30, IP address 173.15.20.33/27, gateway 173.15.20.1 and VLAN 30
